segments.text: I was involved in that whole effort from kind of its embryo stage up until now, and I went out on the third cruise of the Gromar Challenger, and I think we made some fantastic scientific discoveries on that.
We went across the South Atlantic here and drilled a set of holes across Mid-Atlantic Ridge, and for the first time we were really able to
pin down all the things that people had said in seafloor spreading by actually getting samples there and dating them and so on.
And this was the first real evidence of seafloor spreading that was direct, and I think that's a significant accomplishment.
I think between that and the heat flows will be my major accomplishments.
I think I've
had some impact from the administrative side, but it's tougher to evaluate those, and there are a lot of administrators around.
One happens to be lucky enough to be in the right spot at the right time, and you can have some impact on things.
If you're at the wrong time, it's tough.
As historians, we call that the monkey bite theory of history.

Crimean War began because a monkey bit a Turk on the neck, and we've always maintained that those people who believe to be in the right spot at the right time are believers not in great men, but in monkey bite theory.
There's a lot to be said for that.
What direction do you foresee Woods Hole going?
beside more and more applied science.
Is there any particular direction you'd like to take Woods Hole to?
Well, I feel that the one thing that I feel strongest about in making Woods Hole a better place
is to develop its independence from the federal government a little more than it is.
We depend
very highly on grants and contracts.
85% of our support or something comes from that.
And we're pretty much at the whim of the federal governments of what happens to be in vogue this year and so on.
I'd like to see us develop an independence, and perhaps the only way one can do this is through building up the endowment to the point where

we can support a large enough fraction of ourself that we have the independence to do what we feel is right and not what happens to be the thing that the government is supporting at that particular time.
Now, a lot of times these match very nicely.
They match mainly by necessity, I guess.
If we're not doing what the government's supporting, we end up not doing anything.
were forced into that, and I'd like to break away a little bit from this sense of being tied to the government.
I think that's the single biggest change I could foresee happening here.
Do you find personally that there are more bureaucratic entanglements and snares now than there were, say, ten years ago in dealing with the government?
Oh, yes.
Every time you turn around,
And the government is tending to use its contracting powers over a lot of people to accomplish a lot of its social aims.
And sometimes these accomplish the ends, and other times they just cause more complication and cost than they might be working on.

I'm sure you've heard examples of this from the OSHA, the Affirmative Action, to handicap, to all the kind of regulations that get put upon you and make business more costly, more expensive, and hopefully reaching some end.
I think they are useful.
I don't object to what these programs are trying to do.
There may be better ways of accomplishing

And it makes life very complicated here, and we're forced to build up an infrastructure in terms of bureaucracy here to match the bureaucracy that gets put on us by Washington, which tends to make, gets the administration in bad with the scientists, because it looks like we're getting bigger, taking more of their money as they see it, and yet it's one of the necessities in life to do this.
I'm not sure there's any way of getting around it.
But life has become complicated.
Grants seem to be getting smaller.
We're writing more and more proposals.
The proposals are getting more and more complicated, thicker.
We looked at last year and found out that we were
I think we have something of the order of 400 individual grants and contracts at this place here.
It's something of the order of two a working day.
So that means roughly two proposals a day on the average go out of this institution.
It has to be written by somebody and reviewed and read.
Usually these are just for a one-year thing.
Each scientist, on the average, must have about three or four contracts.
He spends a large fraction of his time writing proposals.
It's a waste of effort.
It wasn't this way in the past.
Again, this ties into the peer review system and the competition.
If somehow there are ways to reduce this, and there are ways that you can do this, NSF would simply go to three- or four-year grants and stop a little bit of it.
There are some disadvantages in this.
If you give a grant for three or four years and you fix the budget, by the time the fourth year comes along, the inflation has ruined you and the
The guy dies his fourth year, he can't keep things going because he can't possibly estimate what's going to happen in terms of cost.
But nonetheless, I think longer term grants would be a move in the right direction to get off this proposal writing treadmill that everybody's on.
And it's not restricted to us.
It's the same all over.
There's even talk about seven and ten year grants.
Well, that's an interesting thought.
One ought to think of, if you're going in terms of seven- and ten-year grants, of tying this a little bit in with the tenure system of universities, which is an archaic system.
Maybe there's a better way of doing both of these.

When you talk in terms of specialization of younger oceanographers, I have a feeling that, too, is academic-wide because it's difficult for a young man to be a generalist or work on group projects when he always faces the problems of developing tenure.
That's right.
Not only developing tenure, but he's in this proposal competition in oceanography no matter where he's at.
You've got to be specialized to compete in that.
And the whole tenure system is, well, I don't know that the tenure system is so much set up as specialization.
You've got to make your mark somehow.
And you've got to be able to prove it.
And you usually prove it by publications and so on.
But these can be done.
And it's harder to do in a generalized point of view.
And usually only the more senior people that have been in longer and have a broader overview are capable of doing that.
So it's easier to do this, the more specialized you are, because you know more about it than anyone else in the business.
You're the only guy that's thought about it, essentially.
And it's easier to get ahead that way.
It's essentially the way the whole research game has gone over a number of years.
All right.
So personally, possibly a return to research.
moving more and more away from the federal bureaucracy, possibly in terms of your institution.
What else in the future?
Well, I've spent a lot of my activities in the last few years on things outside of Woods Hole.
And I suspect that's where I get a lot of my satisfaction now.
You know, you can get it out of research, but you've got to be in the trenches on the front line doing the research to get this.
And it's difficult to do research from an administrative position.
I find it very difficult.
You just can't spend the time on it that you need.
And you don't get much satisfaction out of solving everybody else's problems and trying to keep the place going.
So the way that one tends to contribute when you're in an administrative job is doing things on the outside, on committees and so forth.
I'm president of the American Geophysical Union now, which turned out to be more work than I thought.
But again, I find this a satisfying thing to work on these kind of things, spend some time in there.
I guess as time goes on, I might even spend more time.
If I can get free from, get organized well enough to do my inside chores in less time so I have more free time to do it.
What were your major disappointments as an oceanographer?
What did you want desperately to succeed, which failed?
That's the toughest one yet.
I guess I've been pretty fortunate that most of the things have gone pretty well.
I was a little disappointed when the Moho got shot down.
Put a little bit of effort into that.
I think, in general, things have gone.
pretty well.
No real complaints.
Okay.
And I take it if you had all of it over again, you would choose to do it roughly the same way?
I suspect so.
I don't know where I'd make any different decisions right now.
Is there anything you'd like to add to the tape?
No, I can't.
I'm sure that
By the time you're halfway back to Texas, I'll think of a lot of things that I should have mentioned to you.
Hindsight's always easier than foresight.
No, I can't think of anything.
I've enjoyed the opportunity to sit and chat with you this way.
Oh, it's been my pleasure.
You know, it would be interesting, you say you're not going to write this history, you're just making it available online.
For everybody else, on the other hand, you have talked personally to all these people, and you probably have a much better feeling than what's just on tape.
And it seems to me it's a shame that you can't put some kind of story together, even if it's kind of a human interest story on bits and pieces, how you see things fall together and so on.
I have two regrets about this project that I began tonight.
One thing I regret is very simple.
I wish every place I had gone, I had taken a camera.
I'm sorry now that I haven't put together a portfolio of oceanographers.
That'd be interesting.
So that when people listen to the tapes or read the transcript, they couldn't see them.
And the second thing I wish I had done is I wish I had, every time after I had left an interview, I'd sit down with my typewriter for 35 minutes
and typed up my impressions of that individual.
Well, that's the kind of things that I was meaning.
You know, you've got a feeling that goes along with just what's on tape.
And you've talked to a lot of people on this, at least from what I've heard you say, and these are all very knowledgeable people, and I think it would be nice.
I've often wondered why somebody hasn't
put down a good history of oceanography.
And I think just to put it on tape and leave it is kind of a shame.
On the other hand, I suspect you've got another year's worth of taping or something like that.
Probably, if we're financed again, that's certain.
Another year's worth of taping.
I think we need to.
I think also we need to make secondary interviews.
I think one of the things that we need to do, you're speaking of things you remember far away.
I think one thing that...

One weakness in the writing of oceanography is after they put all this down, if they would go back and talk to the people again and see how they perceive it a second time, it'd make a sizable difference to what they're saying.
I had a similar interview with a guy from Stanford who was kind of putting together a history on seafloor spray, plate tectonics.
I've forgotten what his name was.
He was going around the country interviewing a lot of scientists to try and get their opinion of how they thought plate tectonics developed.
And that's sort of the whole story of the field that I've been in.
That's been kind of the crowning glory.
It's been like the Darwin theory of evolution in biology.
It's been that sort of equivalent for geology.
has that much of an impact on geology.
And we were all part of that.
So I'd love to see this story develop sometime.
I don't know whether it'll ever come out or whether it's just going to end up taped there.
But the other thing that has been missing, and you're getting a lot of this, is how oceanography got started in this country.
And guys like
Revell, when he was a commander in the Navy, and Mary Sears, who was working down with him, Charlie Fishu, who was in Rhode Island, went down there for a little while.
These guys were all part of this business getting started.
And it's sort of going by the way.
They're all disappearing now.
Yeah.
Sure are.
And rapidly.
Menzies died last year, you know?
Bob Menzies?
Yes.
I don't know about that.
You know, Sumner Pike, as well as the great ones like Ewing and Islum, there are just not any place for them to take.
That's right.
Sumner would have been a great one to interview.
He's such a bullshitter and a gentleman.
He's a great guy.
I think of him as one of the nicest people I've ever met.
He was just such a great person.
I got to know him quite well.
If you ever have time, it'll take a long time, you'll have to listen to my tape with Roger Revelle.
Oh, I'd love to.
You know, I know Roger so well.
I'm afraid that when Revelle dies, that one of the things they're going to have to understand, that scientists and historians are going to have to understand is why he was so great.
And if you can be with him for a while and captures enthusiasm and human quality, it's just absolutely overwhelming.
Yeah, he is such a compassionate person.
And he's always been that way.
He just doesn't think in small terms or in small things.
I think he's one of the great scientists of our time.
Not that he's so much of a scientist, but he's one of the great figures in science of our time.
Probably more underestimated than almost any.
He just has never I think made the mark that I
really feel that he deserves.
Part of this must be the fact that he changed fields in the middle of his career.
He certainly reached the top in oceanography, and there wasn't much else to go there.
Well, he wanted desperately to be chancellor of San Diego.
Yeah.
I suppose that he being himself and the regents being themselves, the political division was just simply too great.
It's too bad.
Too bad for San Diego.
Too bad for... What do you want to do?
You know, I talked to him when that happened.
I was in Washington.
It was...
saying what, wondering what he should do.
I talked to some people that found out this job was available in the Interior Department.
I think it was Assistant Secretary of Interior.
It wasn't Assistant.
It was sort of Science Advisor for the Interior Department.
And I sort of helped talk them in.
Coming back to Washington, he spent about a year in Washington in that job, as I recall.
And it was a real transition zone.
I guess he went from there to Harvard.
I'm not quite sure.
I assume it was in that job where he worked in Pakistan for a while.
And I think after he got back from there, he went on to the Population Control Center at Harvard.
Well, he certainly continued to work in Pakistan.
He was very worried about the problems of the world and people.
